abstract.para: This file provides documentation for file 92BOHYPO.PRN, an ASCII file that contains final data for hyporheic nutrients and chemistry. Samples were collected from a grid of wells in one control pool/riffle site in both the Kuparuk River and Oksrukuyik Creek.

intellectualRights.para: Acceptance and utilization of LTER data requires that:

listitem.para: The Principal Investigator be sent a notice stating reasons for acquiring any data and a description of the publication intentions.
The Principal Investigator of the data set be sent a copy of the report or manuscript prior to submission and be adequately cited in any resultant publications
A copy of any resultant publications should be sent to:Principal Investigator Ecosystems Center Marine Biological Laboratory Woods Hole, MA 02543

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Kuparuk River - Control: riffle/pool series at 0.45 k Oksrukuyik Creek - Control: riffle/pool series at -1.1 k

description.para:
For Archival Use:
DATE RECEIVED: June 97 DATA FILE ENTERED BY: Karie Slavik DATA FILE VALIDATION: NAME: Karie Slavik DATE: 03Sept97

para.literalLayout: Modified PVC wells were used to sample a grid of sites situated in one pool/riffle continuum in both the Kuparuk River and Oksrukuyik Creek. The wells were of a significantly different design than the stainless steel (SS) and PVC samplers used in 1990 and 1991. The tops of the wells, approximately 4-5 ft. risers, were constructed from 1/2 in. PVC tubing. The well bottoms were constructed from 5 in. of 1/2 in PVC slotted every 1/4 in. The slots were 0.006 in. wide. The slotted PVC was attached to the riser at the top and a polypropylene (PP) well point at the bottom. The slotted PVC and the riser were separated by a silicon stopper which prevented exposure of hyporheic water to the atmosphere. A 5 to 6 ft. length of 1/8 in. SS tubing extended from the slotted PVC chamber through the stopper to several inches above the top of the well (riser). A stopper at the top of the well prevented rain water from entering the riser. The bottom end of the SS was open; the top end was attached to a 1/8 in. Swagelok to a 1/8 in. female NPT fitting. This, in turn, was attached to a 1/8 in. male NPT to 1/8 in. I.D. plastic hose barb. Approximately 2 in. of 1/8 in plastic tubing was attached tightly to the hose barb fitting. The sampling port, a three-way Pharmaseal stopcock, was inserted into the end of the plastic tubing. The sampling apparatus was air-tight Wells were inserted by using a pry bar to create a narrow gap in the streambed cobbles. As the pry bar was carefully removed, the PVC well was quickly inserted to the deepest depth possible, usually 30-70 cm. Wells were located in a grid consisting of 5 to 7 rows, with 2 to 4 wells across each row. Well locations andelevations were mapped in both rivers using a field level and stadia, and referencing all points in each river to a fixed common point. Wells were notsampled for several weeks after installation. To sample wells for nutrients, wells were first purged by drawing slowly on a 60 cc B.D. syringe; following this, up to 100 ml of water was withdrawn and immediately filtered through a 0.45 um, 25 mm syringe filter into an acid-washed 125 ml polypropylene bottle. Filters were first flushed with 5 to 10 ml of sample, which was discarded. Nutrient samples were stored on ice until they could be refrigerated at Toolik Camp prior to analysis with the autoanalyzer. After the nutrient sample was removed from the well, a hand pump was used to pull water into a vacuum flask to measure conductivity, pH, and dissolved oxygen. Well water slowly filled a 30 ml glass vial in the flask and was allowed to overflow several times into the flask. The vial was carefully removed from the flask to avoid entraining air bubbles in the sample, capped, sealed with Parafilm, and stored on ice. Conductivity and pH were immediately measured on the sample remaining in the flask. At Toolik Camp, the vial was opened and dissolved oxygen measured using the Solomat datalogger and MacKreth DO probes with a stirrer. DO was typically measured within 2 to 3 hours of sample collection. Small amounts of sediment in these samples did not appear to create a measureable oxygen demand.

Notes: These data should not be released to any party without first consulting William B. Bowden. (11) VARIABLE DESCRIPTIONS: Precis. Coded? Missing Variable Variable description Units (Y/N) Values

PH pH n . DO Dissolved oxygen mg/liter n .

Calculations: Variable Formula NO3 Done by linear regression on Toolik Technicon Autoanalyzer NH4 Done by linear regression on Toolik Technicon Autoanalyzer PO4 Done by linear regression on Toolik Technicon Autoanalyzer
